question.title: Change Name of Import in Java, or import two classes with the same name
question.body:
In Python you can do a:

from a import b as c

How would you do this in Java, as I have two imports that are clashing.

answers.body:
This is obviously not quite what OP is asking, but I thought I'd point out that this is not too far off from asking whether types can be aliased in Java more generally.

Which, again, the answer is sort-of no, except for the fact that they can be aliased in the context of type variables. Which means you can do this:

class MyClass<IntList extends List<Integer>>
{ /* use IntList inside MyClass
     as if it were a 'type alias' of List<Integer>
  ...
  */
}

So, if you were happy to 'alias' things locally in each class that you are to use that alias in, then you could use this trick, i.e. instead of importing 'either' of the two formatters, alias them locally directly:

class MyClass<FormatterA extends com.text.Formatter,
              FormatterB extends com.json.Formatter>
{ /* Make use of FormatterA and FormatterB */ }
